results.title: Dragonheart
results.creator_credit: Rob Cohen, Raffaella De Laurentiis and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Bowen (Quaid) is a knight dedicated to the Old Code, a noble creed of honour in a time long ago when majestic fire breathers soared through the skies. Bowen dedicates his time to instructing worthy pupils of the Old Code. He is disillusioned when one of his pupils, Prince Einon, becomes a cruel King, and Bowen loses faith in the idealism that was once the source of his inner strength. Believing Einon’s soul to have been poisoned by a dragon, Bowen vows to destroy all dragons - without question or mercy. It is on this revenge quest for the good soul of Prince Einon that Bowen meets Draco (voice provided by Sean Connery), a dragon whose power, strength and wit are not easily defeated. As man and dragon contest in a life or death struggle, a friendship is formed that will change the face of the medieval world forever. Cast includes Dennis Quaid, David Thewlis, Pete Postlethwaite, Julie Christie and Dina Meyer.

results.title: Dot and the Koala
results.brief_description: Dot and the Koala opens with the residents of a small Australian country town desperately wanting to lead more exciting, more modern lives. Major Percy Pig convinces the townspeople - a strange collection of haughty cows, hardworking horses and aggressive dogs - that the answer to their problems is a massive dam. The dam will provide the power to catapult the town into the 21st century. When the native animals - kangaroos, wombats and possums - realise the dam will destroy vast tracts of the countryside, open warfare erupts between the two groups.

results.title: Dot and the Bunny
results.brief_description: Dot ventures into the bush determined to finally locate the little lost Joey and reunite him with his mother the kangaroo. On her way she meets a silly bunny rabbit who tries to convince Dot that he is the lost Joey she is looking for. Dot politely explains to her new friend that Joeys have pouches and long tails, just like other kangaroos. Determined to convince Dot, the bunny fashions a pouch and a tail for himself from some shrubs and leaves. Dot is delighted and nicknames him Funny Bunny. Together they set out to search for the lost Joey and Dot tries to console Funny Bunny by explaining how important bunnies are especially at Easter.

results.title: Donnie Brasco (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Mike Newell, Gail Mutrux, Louis Digiamo, Barry Levinson, Mark Johnson and Mandalay Entertainment
results.brief_description: This is a gangster movie quite like no other which is more concerned with character study, friendship and betrayal. Donnie Brasco (Johnny Depp), also known as Joe the Jeweller, befriends Mafia small man and former assassin Lefty Ruggiero (Al Pacino). Lefty sees in the young Donnie a chance to rise in the Mafia ranks, something the aging Lefty, with his drug addicted son and passive wife is no longer capable of. Unbeknown to Lefty, Donnie Brasco is an under cover special agent, working with the FBI to infiltrate the New York Mafia underworld. What at first seems a simple case of undercover work is complicated by Donnie’s genuine feelings of friendship towards Lefty and Lefty’s loyalty towards Donnie. Based on the book by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. Also starring Michael Madsen, Bruno Kirby, James Russo and Anne Heche.

results.title: Donald in Mathmagic land
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney, Walt Disney Productions and Hamilton Luske
results.brief_description: Donald Duck participates in a remarkable adventure and learns that music, architecture, art and science are all based on mathematical principles. Tracing the history and development of these principles, we find the Arabs responsible for our present numbers and algebra; Egypt the source of geometric theories, the pyramids remaining as a monument to their knowledge of the triangle; and to the Greeks Pythagoras we owe our musical scale.

results.title: Don Juan de Marco
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Leven, Patrick Palmer, Fred Fuchs, Francis Ford Coppola and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Just ten days shy of his retirement, psychotherapist Jack Mickler (Marlon Brando) is brought in by the authorities to help ‘talk down’ a suicidal man (Johnny Depp), devastated by the loss of his lover. Clothed in a cape and mask the heart broken man believes he is the legendary seducer of women, Don Juan De Marco. The doctor takes him on as a patient and through their therapy sessions Don Juan recounts his many romantic adventures and conquests. At first sceptical of the mans sanity, Dr. Mickler is gradually seduced by Don Juan’s outlandish tales of love, leading him to question the fictional nature of his stories and the man’s real identity. It’s not long before Mickler is applying Don Juan’s instructional lessons on his wife (Faye Dunaway). Jeremy Leven’s unashamed paean to romance is given unexpected depth and poignancy from the exceptional cast, starting with the ever charismatic Johnny Depp and the inspired coupling of Marlon Brando and Faye Dunaway. Their intimate husband and wife banter is one of the films highlights. Cast also includes Geraldine Pailhas, Bob Dishy, Rachel Ticotin, Talisa Soto and Selena Perez.

results.title: Don's Party
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams and Art House Productions
results.brief_description: Bruce Beresford’s classic Australian comedy exposes Australian social mores in the suburbs. Don and Kath have invited a group of friends to celebrate what they believe will be a Labor Party victory on Election night. The night begins happily enough until the guests receive the news that Labor is losing. Old enmities erupt as hostilities break out amongst the guests as the party disintegrates into an alcoholic disaster. Cast includes Ray Barrett, Graham Kennedy, John Hargreaves, Graeme Blundell, Jeanie Drynan and Clare Binney.

results.title: Dogma
results.creator_credit: Kevin Smith, Scott Mosier and View Askew Productions
results.brief_description: Director/writer Kevin Smith’s (Clerks, Mallrats, Chasing Amy) comedic interpretation of the Catholic religion caused controversy before its release and continues to do so today, despite Smith’s claim that “Dogma” is about rediscovering your faith in God and shouldn’t be taken too seriously. Dwindling numbers of church-goers has caused the Catholic Church to take desperate measures to ensure its survival, beginning the ‘Catholicism Wow’ campaign, in an attempt to boost the church’s profile. Renegade angels Loki (Matt Damon) and Bartleby (Ben Affleck), banished from Heaven following an argument with God and forced to spend eternity in Wisconsin, discover a loophole in dogmatic law that will allow them to re-enter Heaven, by passing through the arch of a New Jersey Cathedral. Unfortunately God- who happens to be a woman- has failed to return from her monthly visit to earth to play arcade games. As a result the fate of the human race relies on the last descendent of Christ, Bethany (Linda Fiorentino), who has lost her faith. Metatron (Alan Rickman), a Seraphim and the voice of God, informs Bethany of her responsibilities and that she will be assisted by two prophets, Jay (Jason Mewes) and his hetro-life partner Silent Bob (played by director Kevin Smith). The unlikely trio head to New Jersey, to stop Bartleby and Loki from entering the church, because if they do, they will have proven God fallible and will wipe out all human existence. Along their way they are assisted by Rufus (Chris Rock), the 13th apostle, who claims he was left out of the bible for political reasons (and that Jesus owes him $12) and Serendipity (Salma Hayek), a muse with writers block. Cast also includes George Carlin, Jason Lee, Bud Cort, Jeff Anderson, Brian O’Halloran, Janeane Garofalo and Alanis Morissette as God.

constellations_other.name: Divining the divine
constellations_other.description: Depicting the Almighty in paintings was frowned upon in the early 1800s in Britain, much like it has been throughout the history of cinema, according to writer Scot Hughes, who made many of these connections in a 2003 article in the Sydney Morning Herald.
